content:
When talking about a user creating an account, most of our UI says "register", "registration", etc.

That term feels a bit abstract and formal to me, and I don't think I see it used in most places on the Web -- most sites prefer "sign up", which to me feels simpler and more direct. E.g., look (in an incognito window) at facebook.com, twitter.com, community.keyboard.io (which is an install of Discourse), or discordapp.com. All say "Sign Up".

So I think we should probably make a pass through our user-facing text and edit all mentions of "register" and friends to "sign up" etc.

Thoughts?

It's a bit hard to grep directly for this, because "register" is also the term we use in most places in the code and URLs, and that'll be more work to change. But grepping through static/locale/de/ (or any other locale) works well.
haha, clever way to grep for strings...yeah, I agree that "register" always sounded funny to me
This could be a good GCI task

Interesting observation. A lot of sites (though not twitter) also seem to use "Sign in" instead of "Log in".
And yeah, I think it makes sense to switch this to whatever is popular in 2017.
Should we switch to both "Sign up" and "Sign in"? Or "Sign up" and "Log in"?
I will prefer Sign up & Sign in
Opened as #7759
I think I prefer "Log in" -- partly because "Sign in" and "Sign up" look confusingly similar, and partly because "log in" or "login" is what I think of as the usual verb for this.
"Sign in" to me feels like jargon that might be used within a technical discussion.
@Rishi Gupta I just went through the four examples I linked above, and all say either "Log In" or (for Discord) "Login". Where are you seeing "Sign in" used?

interesting! chase.com, dropbox.com, google.com, tsheets.com, github.com, slack.com.
Now that I take a wider sample I see log in (and login)'s as well: asana.com, upwork.com, abacus.com, facebook.com, twitter.com
yahoo.com uses "sign in" (whether they're an example or counterexample, I don't know, but they've had two decades to iterate)

Hmm, seeing it on chase.com reminds me that "Sign in" feels like what I expect on a bank site, for some reason.

Though now going to my credit union (mitfcu.org), it says "log in".

Finding a couple of discussions and surveys on the web:
https://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/1080/using-sign-in-vs-using-log-in
https://www.leemunroe.com/login-vs-signin/

I don't see much of a consistent pattern. Both are common.
Hmm, the latter link (from 2010) shows Twitter with "Sign in" -- they've switched to "Log in" since then.
Anyway, I'm persuaded by the many people reporting that they find "Sign in" and "Sign up" confusing as alternatives, so I wouldn't want to use both of them, even though a few of these sites do.
I'll defend the status quo here as well--there's obviously not a compelling reason to change.
I don't feel strongly about it. Updated the issue.

@Steve Howell Sorry, I didn't make it totally clear after a second issue came in:

0% of the sites I've looked at use "Register". I think it's unambiguous that we should use a better term there.
(And it looks like the issue as Rishi updated it now reflects that, so we may all be in agreement)
I was only talking within the context of sign-in/sign-out, since that's where the conversation seemed to have focused. I think "Sign up" is clearly better than "Register".
